title-group.subtitle: An Efficient Design for Estimating the Accuracy of Patient Safety Indicators

abstract.p: Objective. Accuracy studies of Patient Safety Indicators (PSIs) are critical but limited by the large samples required due to low occurrence of most events. We tested a sampling design based on test results (verification-biased sampling [VBS]) that minimizes the number of subjects to be verified. Methods. We considered 3 real PSIs, whose rates were calculated using 3 years of discharge data from a university hospital and a hypothetical screen of very rare events. Sample size estimates, based on the expected sensitivity and precision, were compared across 4 study designs: random and VBS, with and without constraints on the size of the population to be screened. Results. Over sensitivities ranging from 0.3 to 0.7 and PSI prevalence levels ranging from 0.02 to 0.2, the optimal VBS strategy makes it possible to reduce sample size by up to 60% in comparison with simple random sampling. For PSI prevalence levels below 1%, the minimal sample size required was still over 5000. Conclusions. Verification-biased sampling permits substantial savings in the required sample size for PSI validation studies. However, sample sizes still need to be very large for many of the rarer PSIs.

body.p: In-hospital patient safety has been identified as a top priority internationally.1–6 The Patient Safety Indicators (PSIs) developed by the United States Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) are a set of 18 measures, based on routinely collected administrative data, designed to screen potentially avoidable complications of hospital care, for which high rates might indicate quality concerns.7 The main concern with such indicators is their low sensitivity in flagging incidents. Although regularly used as quality indicators and to benchmark quality,8 PSIs suffer from the shortcomings related to routinely collected administrative data (i.e., underreporting, inaccuracy and variability of diagnosis coding, and disputable preventability of the detected conditions).9,10 On the other hand, the specificity of administrative data–based tools is generally considered high.

Even if PSIs have demonstrated minimal prerequisites for quality measures,7 their widespread acceptance will only occur after additional testing of their diagnostic accuracy against a reference standard, usually the review of the medical record by one or, preferably, several experts.11 Typically, these studies produce 4 measures, from a 2 × 2 contingency table relating test results (i.e., presence or absence of PSIs derived from administrative data) to the reference standard to permit the determination of sensitivity (Se), specificity (Sp), positive predictive value (PPV), and negative predictive value (NPV). Furthermore, the extent of statistical uncertainty (i.e., 95% confidence intervals [CIs]) around the estimates of these 4 parameters ideally should be reported. Despite the widespread use of PSIs in various settings, the 4 parameters discussed here are not well characterized for most PSIs.12–15

In large screened populations, the simplest sampling design to assess diagnostic accuracy (in terms of sensitivity and specificity and the desired width of their associated 95% CI) is to verify a simple random sample drawn from this relevant clinical population to determine the presence of the disorder, independently from the test result. In this sampling design, often referred to as simple random sampling (SRS), the same fraction (e.g., 10%) of screened positive and negative test results is verified. As the conditions of interest with PSIs are usually rare (most event rates are less than 2%), large samples are needed, and most subjects have negative test results and do not have the condition. This approach results in large expenditures devoted to data collection in subjects who are clinically less relevant than those with the condition of interest. More efficient sampling strategies have been proposed, depending on study design (either prospective or retrospective) and the existence of prior knowledge of prevalence of the condition in different strata of risk factors.16 When the true condition is already known, a retrospective case-control design (where sampling is done from 2 lists of patients: with and without the target adverse event) may be used. This is, however, not feasible with most PSIs, as the presence or absence of a PSI target condition is generally unknown ahead of chart review.

When sensitivity is predictable in subgroups of persons, an alternative design is stratified random sampling (STR). In this approach, the target population is divided into exhaustive and nonoverlapping groups (i.e., strata) of different levels of sensitivity, and SRS is drawn in each stratum for verification. The more homogeneous the sensitivity is within and heterogeneous across strata, the larger the gain of efficiency.17 The difficulty here, however, lies in identifying those strata. If the prevalence of the condition is related to sensitivity, then stratification by expected prevalence may prove useful.16 The gain of efficiency over SRS, however, largely depends on the true relationship between prevalence and sensitivity, which has not yet been studied for PSIs. Misclassification errors depend mainly on the quality of medical information encoding, which may or may not be related to prevalence of the condition. But more importantly, coding errors, missing codes, and coding practices vary markedly across hospitals or settings. STR is indeed an interesting approach, but validation studies (where the true condition is being assessed) are prerequisites to devise appropriate strata based on sensitivity prediction through multivariable risk modeling.

Another approach, which has a long history in survey sampling, is to enroll participants prospectively according to test results and to determine the true condition afterwards; thus, one may oversample positively screened subjects for verification on chart reviews and reduce the large number of negative test results to verify. This selective sampling scheme has been referred to as 2-phase sampling or verification-biased sampling (VBS) because, unless properly accommodated, estimates of sensitivity and specificity are biased (Table 1).16,18 When disease prevalence is low but the main study goal is nonetheless to estimate sensitivity, Irwig and others have shown that, for a given CI width, a VBS design can provide substantial savings in the sample size required for verification.19 A recent validation study of one PSI (PSI 12) used a VBS design with a fixed number of positive and negative cases verified.20

body.p: Comparing sample sizes in settings with and without various screening constraints would be useful. Such constraints arise, for example, when screening has not yet occurred and diagnostic tests are inconvenient or even dangerous (invasive test) or costly. In PSI accuracy studies, one may wish to minimize both the size of the screened population because of the small size of the hospital, the long accrual time required to gather a large enough screened population, and the sample size for verification (e.g., because of resource constraints). The 2 goals, however, contradict, as the size of the screened population does have an impact, albeit relatively small, on the sample size for verification. Furthermore, the minimal required size of the screened population depends considerably on the sampling design one wishes to adopt for verification, for example, SRS, VBS with optimal, or VBS with predefined fixed sampling fractions. For instance, when screening is costly or inconvenient, VBS with optimal sampling fractions (which often requires a very large screened population) may not always be the best solution. A better compromise may be reached by sampling using nonoptimal (i.e., predetermined or fixed) fractions. In other settings, the investigator may desire to verify all positive test results (where likely most clinically meaningful patients are found) and only a fixed or minimal fraction of negative test results.

Our goal was, therefore, to compare the efficiency of various sampling designs (SRS v. VBS), in settings with and without constraints on the screened population, in the context of PSI accuracy studies. Simulation scenarios are presented using previously published rates of PSI true condition and PSI accuracy.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: In this section, we describe how to compute estimators for parameters of a diagnostic test (in our case, PSI screening algorithms applied to administrative data) and how to estimate sample sizes when a VBS design has been used.

sec.title: Point Estimators of Screening Algorithm Accuracy
sec.p: The left part of Table 1 summarizes the complete data set from a random sample of N subjects drawn from a relevant clinical population. All N subjects are tested and verified for accuracy on chart review. The sensitivity (estimated by a/(a + c)) is the proportion of diseased subjects (i.e., inpatients with the specified adverse event found in the medical record) declared positive by the screening tool (i.e., the algorithm applied to hospital routinely collected data). The specificity (estimated by d/(b + d)) is the proportion of nondiseased subjects (inpatients with no specified adverse event in the medical record) declared negative by the screening tool. The PPV is estimated by a/(a + b), and the NPV by d/(c + d).

The right part of Table 1 summarizes the data set from a VBS situation where unequal fractions f0 of negative test results and f1 of positive test results have been sampled. Because usually a smaller fraction of observations with negative results undergo confirmatory testing (i.e., f0 < f1), the apparent sensitivity (i.e., a&/(a& + c&)) is overestimated and the apparent specificity (i.e., d&/(b& + d&)) underestimated. However, PPV (i.e., a&/(a& + b&)) and NPV (i.e., d&/(c& + d&)) estimates are unbiased, provided negative and positive screen results have been sampled at random. According to this so-called missing at random (MAR) assumption, the decision to ascertain disease is independent of the true status. sec.title: Calculating Sample Sizes
sec.p: The sample size estimates are based on the desired width of the 100(1 – α)% CI for sensitivity. We focused on sensitivity because, in situations where the prevalence of a condition is low, the same level of precision for specificity requires smaller sample sizes than for sensitivity.21 Moreover, in situations of very low prevalence, less than 0.01 for instance, the negative test result proportion provides a good approximation for specificity. Actually, the negative test result proportion provides a lower bound for specificity, whereas the negative test result proportion plus the prevalence provides an upper bound.1

For the VBS design, asymptotic 100(1 – α)% CIs for sensitivity and specificity are derived using the asymptotic variance formulas of Begg and Greenes (Appendix, section 1).23 As previously shown by Irwig and others19 (equation 4 in Appendix, section 1), the optimal sampling design, that is, the smallest number n of subjects selected for verification in the screened population of size N > n, for a desired CI width can be calculated as follows. First, find the optimal sampling fraction ωopt of positive test results that minimizes the variance of the sensitivity:

It is remarkable indeed that this optimal value only depends on the expected sensitivity and specificity. Then, given this optimal fraction and the required variance of sensitivity, the minimal number of subjects required for verification can be calculated for the various screening settings and sampling designs (Appendix, section 2). The formulas in the Appendix (section 2) are slightly more general than those provided by Irwig and others19 and allow readers to specify fixed (i.e., predetermined or nonoptimal) sampling fractions (e.g., f1 = 1 and f0 = 0.1). This may be particularly useful in the setting with screening constraints, where these fractions influence notably the required size of the screened population. Also, even without screening constraints, fixed fractions may be useful when the investigator wishes to verify all positive test results and determine the smallest negative sampling fraction required.

The impact of the different screening settings and sampling designs was assessed by the consecutive change in percentage of the sample size of subjects to be verified for a specified CI width for sensitivity. We also examined the expected precision of other parameters of each algorithm and the ratio of reviews on true cases (i.e., all hospitalizations with the event of interest) and reviews on noncases (i.e., hospitalizations where no adverse event was identified). All calculations were conducted using STATA version 10.1 (STATA Corporation, College Station, TX).

sec.title: Examples
sec.p: Eighteen PSIs (7 for surgery, 3 for deliveries, and 8 for medical or surgical stays) have recently been endorsed and updated by the AHRQ from the International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes.24 Based on the original AHRQ ICD-9-CM PSIs, corresponding ICD-10 coding algorithms to screen administrative data for the events of interest have been developed through a process of translation by an international group of health service researchers.25 Among them, 3 PSIs that reflected rather contrasted frequencies in empirical analyses conducted by the AHRQ on a large sample of a hospitalized population in the United States were considered in our study: PSI 18, obstetric trauma–vaginal delivery with instrument (22.4%); PSI 19, obstetric trauma–vaginal delivery without instrument (8.6%); and PSI 3, decubitus ulcer (2.1%).26 The source population for applying the 3 algorithms was all patients >18 years old hospitalized in the Centre Hospitalier Universitaire Vaudois (CHUV), an academic medical center in Switzerland, who were discharged between 1 January 2002 and 31 December 2004 after a length of stay of 1 day or more. The population at risk was selected according to the AHRQ specifications.24 Inclusion and exclusion criteria required various combinations of several variables among routinely collected diagnostic and procedure code data, diagnosis-related group specifications, age, and length of stay.

Prevalences (i.e., P(D = 1) in our notations) of each of the 3 conditions were estimated based on a focused search of the recent relevant literature and discussions with medical consultants who work at the CHUV. Published proportions of patients with clinical third- or fourth-degree perineal lacerations after instrumental delivery (i.e., PSI 18) indicate wide variations, from 4% to over 20%.27–29 In normal spontaneous vaginal delivery, severe lacerations (i.e., PSI 19) were less frequent, with less than 1% to 5%.29 A 1-day prevalence study of overt pressure ulcers (i.e., PSI 3) in 40 hospitals and 7000 patients in Germany in 2002 gave a proportion of 5%.30 These proportions ranged from 0.8% in the not-at-risk group to 11% in the at-risk group. Large studies in other countries showed comparable results.31,32

Based on the literature and discussions with the medical team, we expected the following proportions for PSIs in the CHUV: 2% for pressure ulcer, 20% for obstetrical trauma with instrumental vaginal delivery, and 3% for trauma without instrumental vaginal delivery.

We also examined which sensitivity values could be expected. The sensitivity of the PSIs to measure third- and fourth-degree perineal lacerations exceeded 75% in the study of Romano and others.15 However, less than 70% of other types of obstetrical trauma were coded. In our analyses, the sensitivity of pressure ulcer coding was considered to be only 30% because the documentation of this condition is often inconsistent. Berlowitz and others found that the hospital discharge data set captured the occurrence of pressure ulcers in only 31% of cases.33 The sensitivity of obstetrical trauma was considered fair (70%) in instrumental assisted deliveries. We used a more pessimistic estimate of sensitivity for normal spontaneous deliveries (50%) because these procedures often are not conducted by medical doctors. We considered, in addition, a fourth scenario with a very low prevalence of true events (0.5%) and poor sensitivity because proportions in no less than 10 PSIs were found to be smaller than 1%.25,34
In the next section, using these 4 examples, we contrasted the impact of the different screening settings and sampling strategies on the sample sizes of persons screened and verified.

sec.p: Although VBS is more efficient in general, validation studies of most PSIs that screen very rare events will require, for a prevalence of positive test results similar to the disease prevalence, still over 5000 to 6000 medical record reviews (Tables 3 and 4, hypothetical PSI). Moreover, it dictates a need to screen large populations, even within a minimal screen-constrained setting (N = 77,442).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We have illustrated with real data that selectively sampling positive and negative test results based on optimally calculated fractions can reduce the number of medical records that need to be checked to make a valid assessment of patient safety. However, because the conditions to be detected by PSIs are typically of low prevalence, the sample of subjects required for verification will still be quite large. Other sampling strategies, such as stratified 2-stage sampling may prove very useful once appropriate strata have been defined. In the case of PSI studies, this is, however, a difficult task, which requires further research, as the population has to be stratified according to sensitivity and not simply prevalence.

Compared to SRS, VBS can notably reduce the sample size required for estimating the sensitivity of PSIs with specified precision, especially if the expected sensitivity is low. Moreover, PPV, NPV, and specificity are almost always estimated with greater precision than by SRS. Furthermore, the review will generate more useful information because hospitalizations with a higher risk of safety issues are oversampled. Our findings concur with the few previous publications on optimal designs for the estimation of sensitivity and specificity for a broader range of expected values of sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence. These studies have shown that the VBS design is more effective when sensitivity is low to moderate (<0.7) and prevalence is low (≤0.1) and much less when sensitivity increases over 0.8.21 In cases of very high prevalence (>0.5), however, the arguments are reversed, and savings are greater for higher sensitivities.

Because the major cost of accuracy studies of PSIs is the verification of the condition in the medical record, the VBS method can be recommended for most indicators with an expected prevalence over 1%, where sample size for verification is manageable. In the US data, PSI prevalences have varied from less than 0.01% to 25%; some misadventures like transfusion errors or foreign bodies left in during a procedure were indeed rare events.26 Incidentally, the PSI prevalences observed in our study are in agreement with published proportions from other countries.8,35 Given that the expected true prevalence of most targeted safety events probably does not exceed 2%, even using an optimal VBS design will still require large, and costly, validity studies. In most cases, over 1000 medical records should be reviewed. In addition, using the VBS approach means that a very large population needs to be screened. Thus, study duration may turn out to be prohibitive, particularly when it may not be possible or convenient to gather information from different hospitals. For instance, in our hypothetical example, to implement the optimal design required about 80,000 subjects, from which less than 6500 were selected for verification, compared with around 16,000 for the SRS approach. When sampling is performed in different hospitals, however, there will be some loss of power due to the existence of intrahospital correlation, and the variances and sample size formula given in the text must be adapted.

When cases with a potential safety issue are identifiable from registries, through the hospital reporting system, an alternative option is to conduct a case control study, where the true condition status is the criterion for enrollment and the diagnostic test is assessed. This is, however, seldom feasible in our case because registries of most of the adverse events screened by PSIs are lacking. This design has been used for estimating the sensitivity of coding perineal lacerations and decubitus ulcers in an administrative database in specific situations where detailed clinical information was gathered in a prospective study.33,36 Nevertheless, the case control design has been criticized for overestimating test accuracy (i.e., sensitivity and specificity) when compared with studies recruiting patients without consideration of the disease status.37 Indeed, more serious events are more likely to be declared in the case registry and also more likely to be coded in the routinely collected discharge record, thereby overestimating sensitivity.

Another possibility is to consider a stratified sampling design, where subjects from subpopulations with higher sensitivities are more heavily sampled. Obuchowksi and others16 illustrated the potential efficiency gain (in terms of cost savings) from stratifying the target population by a dichotomous factor when the prevalence and sensitivity were different in the 2 sampling strata. Factors for risk stratification, however, are not obvious in PSI diagnostic accuracy studies, where the relationship between prevalence and sensitivity is disputable. When classification of true condition status is based on dichotomization of an underlying continuous trait and in the presence of measurement errors, a relationship between prevalence and sensitivity has been shown to exist.38 The situation, however, is less clear with PSIs, which are truly dichotomous entities. It is difficult in this setting to anticipate how sensitivity is related to prevalence, as many factors may affect the quality of coding, such as patient case mix, but also diagnostic category, type of hospital or medical service, and so on.39 Validation studies based on a VBS design would, indeed, be useful to identify factors related to sensitivity. Once these factors have been identified, stratified sampling based on a risk (or propensity) score may be an interesting alternative to VBS, particularly in very low prevalence settings. The gain of efficiency will depend, however, on the homogeneity of within and heterogeneity of between strata sensitivity and, therefore, on how well the propensity score allows prediction of sensitivity. If the model poorly predicts the condition, stratification based on the risk score may not perform well (even worse than SRS in extreme cases).

Furthermore, devising optimal strata, as well as optimally allocating sample sizes between positive and negative test results within each stratum, is rather complex. The number, as well as the location of the cut points, of the strata must be determined, along with optimal Neyman allocation.40,41 In the case of simple random stratified sampling, Neyman allocation depends only on the sensitivity and weight associated with each stratum.42 However, the extension to VBS within each stratum is less straightforward. Obuchowksi and others16 did not consider Neyman optimal allocation within strata but rather proposed to verify all positive test results and a fraction of negative test results. This hard topic requires further developments and comparative analyses of the efficiency of these various sampling schemes.

Yet, still another alternative, when previous studies have provided accuracy values, is to verify all positive test results only and compute, in addition to PPV, 2 other parameters of interest: the detection probability (DP), that is, the proportion of subjects that screen positively and have the condition (a/N); and the false referral probability (FP), that is, the proportion of subjects that screen positively and do not have the disease (b/N).43 These are binomial proportions allowing straightforward calculation of CIs. Like PPV, DP and FP depend on both the prevalence of the condition and the accuracy of the screening test, but they are useful when comparing the accuracy of 2 tests. In fact, the relative ratio of DP is similar to the relative sensitivity and the relative ratio of FP similar to 1 – specificity (i.e., DP1/DP2 = Se1/Se2 and FP1/FP2 = Sp1/Sp2).

Our work, although motivated by PSI validity studies, can be applied more broadly. It should be particularly useful in any situation where both screening and assessment of the true condition are expensive or invasive and the expected test sensitivity is low, especially when the prevalence is low and the specificity is high, and the true prevalence of the condition is not known in advance. We have written a computer program in STATA (which is available upon request), allowing users not only to find the optimal sampling design but also to fix the level of the desired fractions of positive and negative test results. In applied clinical studies, investigators could actually be more concerned by reducing negative test results to be verified than by minimizing the total number of subjects. Inputting into the software the fractions of positive test results f1 set to 1 and of negative test results f0 set to less than 1 allows the comparison of the precision of the fixed fraction sampling design with that of the optimal VBS and random sampling.

The limitations of our study largely overlap with the limitations of the approach itself, which have already been stated. We have applied the proposed scenarios to data obtained from one medical center, a nonrepresentative sample. In addition, the quality of coding may not be perfect, although analyses have proved that quality of coding is high in this hospital. These 2 elements are not crucial for the use of the data we have made. In fact, it is the flaws of administrative data coding that motivate the need for PSI validation studies, for which the VBS design can be considered.
